import React from "react"; import "./App.css"; import Compass from "./Compass.js"; import ContentParallax from "./ContentParallax.js"; import PageContent from "./PageContent.js"; const url = "localhost:3000"; // sections = ["analysing", "ideating", "building", "evaluating"] function App() { return (

I am

Design principles are

My fight for better design started by realizing that it was up to me, a developer trainee at Nokia, to decide how a web application should work. I had no idea what most of the data handled by that website meant. Oh, KPI stands for key performance indicator? Still boggled. Who found these indicators valuable and why? Since then, I've made sure to always answer that question first.{" "}

Surveys

To be fair, we knew exactly who was using the system as well as the indented purpose. I just didn't know how. Fast forward a couple of years, I started working as a UX designer at a startup called Elk, where I did my thesis while studying at KTH in Stockholm. The new goals set during a pandemic spring required prompt action to find the right direction. As we set out to develop the Aloha service{" "} to enable musicians to work remotely, instead of the familiar B2B approach, one had to not only reach enthusiastic users, but also map out their needs, desires and attitudes. As my first task, I designed an extensive user study based on experience gained during business development labs at the EIT Digital master school. It eventually reached 445 volunteer beta testers and was, according to the CFO, commercially extremely valuable, giving us insights on both the features and the pricing of the product.

Indeed, well thought-out online questionnaires haven't failed me in directing a design towards the right way. Once prospective, active or past users have been reached, getting to know them personally, statistically and as the users of your product is everything. I've made us of this very technique to validate businesses during case winning hackathon projects and best graded university courses. During The Sthlm Tech Fest 2019 "Hackathon for women" we developed a platform, Oasis, that enabled collectively sharing and building green areas in the urban environment. The owners of green areas (be it a city, an organization or an individual) could find gardeners to maintain or fully design a planting for that space. This responded to the needs of those living in a small city flat with a longing for gardening and significantly reduced the the costs of keeping public spaces attractive. Thus, values provided by the platform well represented those of the company: mental health, community and a positive environmental impact.
